top_comment.text:
The guy discussing flash trading in this video is making shit up to sell a 
book.  I worked as a proprietary trader for many years, and hearing him 
talk about this stuff in such a misleading way, and using your average 
viewers ignorance of day-trading, *to make it seem like some big scam is 
going on*, is painful.  It's sad that Cenk takes it at face-value with no 
real understanding of what day-trading entails.  Is there corruption in the 
financial market?  You bet your ass there is, but it's not from flash 
trading, credit trading, and chop-shop daytraders.  Market trading, ECN's, 
and such are regulated to the extreme, and in a good way, so they 
constantly have regulatory changes to help keep things balanced and working 
proper.
The majority of this flash trading is bot programs running, they're not 
personally going "ahead" of you and buying your order and selling it back.  
It's a fucking stock exchange, you CHOOSE where you want to buy.  You can 
punch in and pay the price of buying NOW, or you can try and get a better 
price by putting an order out at a better price, and waiting to get 
filled.  You can put an order to buy at the $1 mark of a $30 stock.  And it 
probably will never get filled.  This doesn't mean people buying at the 
level 2 price are cheating you.  To anyone who has any basic knowledge 
about day-trading or investing, what he says in that short video clip is 
laughably stupid.  Does having a good internet connection and being 
geographically closer to the exchange give you an infinitesimally small 
advantage ?  Yes it does, but your average joe isn't punching in with 
hundreds of thousands in worth of stock, in and out, at the blink of an 
eye.  So he doesn't care.  All he cares about is that that volume is there, 
to make his much smaller trades, safe to actually make.
Again, the reason why day-trading can be profitable for a regular joe, is 
specifically because the amount of extra size and volume this type of 
trading brings in.  Remember, more volume is good for your average joe, it 
makes a stock safer to trade on.  If you're trading on a stock without a 
lot of day-traders and bots holding at prices, the stock wildly fluctuates, 
and you lose money and get pushed out scarily fast.   And what he says 
about "front-running" is atrociously stupid.  Anyone can subscribe to a 
level 2 quotes service, and pay money to have access to a few ECN's to 
trade with, and see where all the orders are sitting at.  *THAT IS WHAT 
DAY-TRADING IS*.  So yes, even you can pay for said services, and see this 
exact same thing on your home computer. (Which he's inferring is a way of 
"cheating" lol)
When you invest through your bank, the people at the bank have some level 
of this quote service as well.  Except the bank covers the cost of using 
ECN's, and whatever else they're subscribing to, by charging YOU an 
exorbitant amounts per-trade, and having ridiculous spreads you have to 
fill just to start making money.  The only real scam with investing in the 
stock market, is when you have middle-men like banks come in, and try to 
manage your money for you, and make money off your gains with stupidly big 
spreads.

*Short version*:  Google a "level 2 quote system " and look at pictures of 
them.  This is not a cheat or some scam.  That's how day trading is done.  
You can use it and do it from home yourself if you have a few hundred 
thousand dollars you don't mind risking. ﻿

comments.text:
I'm not in the US, so I'm not familiar with 401k's, but if your retirement 
savings strategy revolves around the idea that the overall stock market has 
historically always increased in value (i.e. you're buying and holding, and 
not doing a lot of buying and selling), then I wouldn't expect these flash 
traders to have too much impact on your investments.  I say this because, 
with this approach, you're not really trying to time the market that much 
when you buy; you're just trying to get in and hold your investments for 
many many years.  So if you pay 1% more for a stock index than you could 
have, it may be negligeable in the long run.  Now, if you're investing in 
some mutual fund where the manager does a lot of trading, then maybe the 
loss on all those trades could add up. 

However, I do wonder what the overall effect of these flash traders is.  
I.e. are they artificially inflating the overall value of the stock market? 

I should say that I'm by no means an investment expert, so please correct 
me if my comments are incorrect.

top_comment.text:
The stock market should be replaced with an internet stock exchange. Let's 
say you want to sell 100 shares of Microsoft, and people around the world 
combined want to sell 10,000 shares of Microsoft. Then, if someone wants to 
buy 100 shares of Microsoft, they buy it from the big pot, and the amount 
of stock you sell is proportional to the total being sold. So in this case, 
you'd sell 1 share to this buyer, because your shares represent 1% of the 
10,000 shares available. You can also put in the highest/lowest price you 
want to buy/sell for, that way you can just put however much money or 
however many shares you want into the system, tell it to buy/sell at the 
price you want, and let it be. If nobody buys within your range, you won't 
be included in the pool, so you wont lose stock or get money. If nobody 
sells within your range, the computer will wait with your money until it 
finds the stock at the price you want, or you tell it to do something else 
with your money. If your demands are unreasonable, the stock price will 
never get to where you want it, and you'll either be waiting forever, or 
you'll have to come back and change the price you set. If you want to buy 
or sell immediately, you can set it to trade at the market price, which 
would be determined by computer algorithms based on the prices at which the 
stock is trading.
This system would be set up and run by the government, and it would be 
highly regulated to make sure nobody hacks the system. Backups and security 
features would protect against a system crash. It could even be run by an 
intergovernmental organization, such as the UN, EU, or G7. Since it's 
government, it would either be maintained with tax dollars, or a small 
membership fee, or a small transaction fee (like 1%.) ﻿

comments.text:
Currently they are building new transatlantic communication cables so that 
Wall Street can trade at an even faster rate.  
http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2013/02/high-frequency-trading-danger-risk-wall-street
Verizon can't get a cable across the street, but there's no trouble when it 
comes to running a new cable across the fucking atlantic ocean.  We already 
have some, of course, but almost any new infrastructure that is being built 
is probably being built for the rich. 
You can cut out almost all of what you said and just keep a transaction 
fee.  That alone would change *everything*.  But, amusingly, 1% would be 
considered much too high for a transaction fee.  There are a number of 
countries that already have a transaction tax, but for the vast majority of 
them, they are less than 0.5%, and yet that is actually more than enough.  
Most of the money made on Wall Street is done through "leveraging", which 
is when you take out a loan so that you can put more money on a bet.  
Typically Wall Street functions on 1/10 of one-percentage point with they 
refer to as "points".  So 0.5% with regard to anything is "5 points". 
Much of their trading is based on how confident they are that there will be 
some change in value of a few points.  If you bet $1,000 on a 1-point bet, 
then you'd only make a dollar.  But if you borrow $10,000,000 and put all 
of that on the same bet, then you'd get $10,000, and you can just give back 
the $10,000,000 that you borrowed.  That's pretty much what they are doing 
there when they are not busy rigging the market or trying to trick people 
into given them money.  When you hear about all the money they are betting, 
that's what it is referring to.  And what happens if instead of a +1-point 
change, there is a negative 100-point change?  Well, they end up losing a 
million bucks that is usually due, immediately. 
People get burned there all the time, but what usually happens is that if 
you have an underling, then you would have already placed the blame on him 
or somehow left him holding the hot potato.  So even if you make it, on 
your own, to Wall Street and start trying to make it big, you usually end 
up having to start off as someone's bitch who works you 100 hours a week, 
and is constantly trying to trick you into doing things (while showing you 
how they are so smart at tricking other people). 
The 2008 crash is what happens when that hot potato gets so big that only 
the really big boys can hold it, and so they end up getting stuck with it.
